_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Chapter 1.  Executive Summary



1.1  Introduction



The City of Thomson has completed a Risk Management Plan

consistent with Section 112 (r)(7) of the Clean Air Act and Part

68 of Volume 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations.  These

procedures seek to provide for employee safety, public health, and

response agency interaction with respect to the disinfection

process.



1.1.1     Regulations and Threshold Quantities

In June 1996, Section 112(r) was promulgated by United States

Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) dealing with chemical risk

management and risk reduction.  From this rule, all facilities

with a quantity of a regulated substance greater than the

threshold quantity for that substance in a process must comply

with Section 112(r).  One of these chemicals is chlorine.

Chlorine amounts that exceed the regulatory threshold quantity of

2,500 pounds (found in 40 CFR 68.130) are regulated under Section

112(r).



1.1.2     Water Treatment Facilities

The City of Thomson/McDuffie County owns and operates two water

treatment facilities - Big Creek Water Plant and Augusta Road

Water Plant.  The Big Creek Water Plant withdraws raw water from

J. Strom Thurmond Lake. The Augusta Road Water Plant withdraws

water from Usry's Pond.   Finished water from the plants are

disinfected with chlorine and distributed to residents and

numerous industries in the City of Thomson and McDuffie County.

The chlorination process equipment at each plant includes one-ton

chlorine cylinders, chlorination equipment, electrical equipment,

and a chlorine gas detection system.



1.2  Worst Case and Alternative Release Modeling



Modeling was performed using RMP*Comp for both the worst case and

alternative scenario to determine the potential consequences

associated with an accidental chlorine gas release.  For each

plant, atmospheric dispersion modeling was used to determine the

distance traveled by the chlorine gas before its concentration

decreases to a the

oretical "toxic endpoint".



1.2.1     Worst Case Release Results

The worst case scenario, defined by USEPA, states that ".the owner

or operator shall assume that the.maximum quantity in the largest

vessel.is released as a gas over 10 minutes."  For each facility,

the worst case scenario involves failure of a one-ton cylinder

yielding a cumulative release of 2,000 pounds of chlorine over a

duration of ten minutes.  The distance to "toxic endpoint" was 1.3

miles for both plants.



1.2.2     Alternative Release Results

The alternative (more likely) scenario involves mechanical failure

of one flexible manifold connections (pigtail) allowing an

unnoticed release to occur through this hole for one hour.  The

distance to "toxic endpoint" under this alternative was 0.1 miles

for both plants.  In support of the probability that a worst case

scenario is not likely to occur, a review of process history

indicates that no reportable accidental releases (greater than ten

pounds) has occurred in the past five years at the Big Creek or

Augusta Road plants.



1.2.3     Impacts to Population and the Environment

As part of these modeling scenarios, population and environmental

sites are indexed within the radii associated with the worst and

alternative release scenarios.  While the Augusta Road plant lies

in an urban environment, affecting mostly residential receptors,

the Big Creek plant is predominantly rural, mostly affecting

wildlife and recreational users.



1.2.4     Accident History

No reportable accidental releases have occurred at the Big Creek

or Augusta Road plants in the last five years.



1.3  Risk Management Plan Elements



The following key elements are included in the City of Thomson's

RMP:



Operator Training

Preventative Maintenance Program

Chlorine Gas Detection Equipment

Standard Operating Procedures

Hazard Review of Equipment and Operating Procedures

Compliance Auditing



1.3.1     Chlorine Safety Equipment

Both the Big Cree

k and Augusta Road plants utilize equipment

specifically designed to support the safe handling of chlorine and

the chlorination process.  Some of that equipment includes

respiratory protection (SCBA), chlorine gas detectors, chemical

right-to-know (material safety data sheets - MSDS), and personal

protective equipment (safety glasses, rubber apron/gloves, etc.).



1.3.2     Coordination with  Emergency Management Agency

The Big Creek and Augusta Road plants have an emergency response

plan coordinated in conjunction with the Thomson Fire Department

and McDuffie County Emergency Management Agency (EMA).  The City

will also work with Columbia County EMA and Richmond County

Hazardous Materials Response Team (HAZMAT) to learn of their

experiences in an effort to refine and improve upon the City's

emergency response procedures.



Emergency response drills, drill evaluations, and facility tours

are operated annually at which time emergency operation and

response training procedures are also reviewed.  Joint training

sessions with the Fire Department are also used to provide a forum

for maintaining effective chlorine handling procedures and timely

emergency response to potential chlorine hazards.



1.3.3     RMP Management System

The following individuals, assigned by title, are responsible for

the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP.

These individuals will communicate information relating to the RMP

to all other staff involved in the operation and maintenance of

the Big Creek and Augusta Road plants and in the emergency

response for both the plants.







RMP Element    Responsible Employee by Title

Overall Responsibility: RMP Manager     City Administrator

Alternate RMP Manager    Water Superintendent

Safety Information  Water Superintendent

Hazard Review  Water Superintendent

Operating Procedures     Water Superintendent

Training  Water Superintendent

Maintenance    Water Superintendent

Compliance Audits   Fire Chief

Incident Investigation   Fire Chief

Emergency Planning and Response    Fire Chief

RMP Updates (every 5 years and changes) City Administrator
